title: Derek Stark (rugby union)
text:
Derek Stark (born 13 April 1966 in <a href="Kilmarnock">Kilmarnock</a>) is a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> former international <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who played for <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> at the <a href="Rugby%20union%20positions%2314.%20%26amp%3B%2011.%20Wing">Wing</a> positions
Rugby Union career.
Amateur career.
Stark grew up in Kilmarnock playing rugby with <a href="Kilmarnock%20RFC">Kilmarnock RFC</a> and working in his parents hotel there, The Foxbar Hotel. 
As a teenager he moved south to England to study a catering course in Woking at the Tante Marie Culinary Academy. While he was there he played amateur rugby for <a href="Guildford%20Rugby%20Club">Guildford & Godalming RFC</a> and <a href="Chobham%20Rugby%20Football%20Club">Chobham RFC</a>.
After a sojourn into athletics, on seeing the top Caribbean athletes run slightly quicker, Stark moved back into rugby playing for <a href="Boroughmuir%20RFC">Boroughmuir RFC</a>.
Stark played for <a href="Ayr%20RFC">Ayr RFC</a>
He went on to play for amateur side <a href="Glasgow%20Hawks">Glasgow Hawks</a>.
Stark played for <a href="Melrose%20RFC">Melrose RFC</a> He played half a game for Melrose; one of the ten club sides that he played for.
Stark again played for <a href="Boroughmuir%20RFC">Boroughmuir RFC</a>. and won the BT Cellnet Cup with them in 2001.
Provincial and professional career.
He represented <a href="Glasgow%20District%20%28rugby%20union%29">Glasgow District</a> at U21 as well as 7s.
Stark was again picked for Glasgow District when back at Ayr RFC.
He was part of Glasgow District's famous 1989-90 side which went unbeaten all season, winning that year's <a href="Scottish%20Inter-District%20Championship">Scottish Inter-District Championship</a> outright.
On the amateur provincial Glasgow District's move into professionalism in 1996 as Glasgow Rugby - now <a href="Glasgow%20Warriors">Glasgow Warriors</a> - Stark signed a professional contract with the Glasgow side. The move came at a time when Stark was considering a move to play for <a href="West%20Hartlepool%20RFC">West Hartlepool RFC</a>.
As the Wing named for Warriors first match as a professional team - against <a href="Newbridge%20RFC">Newbridge</a> in the <a href="European%20Challenge%20Cup">European Challenge Cup</a> - Stark has the distinction of being given <a href="List%20of%20Glasgow%20Warriors%20players">Glasgow Warrior No. 14</a> for the provincial side.
International career.
Stark played for <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-21%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland U21</a>, <a href="Scotland%20Club%20XV">Scotland Club XV</a>, <a href="Scotland%20B%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland B</a>, <a href="Scotland%20A%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland A</a> and <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> as well as <a href="Scotland%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Scotland 7s</a>.
He notably scored a try on his international Scotland debut in 1993.
Athletics career.
From rugby union, Stark tried his hand at being a sprinter, He could run in 10.6 seconds. 
Business career.
For a short period, Stark - along with international teammates <a href="Rowen%20Shepherd">Rowen Shepherd</a> and <a href="Gregor%20Townsend">Gregor Townsend</a> - owned a bar in Edinburgh's Grassmarket area. The bar was aptly named The Three Quarters.
Alongside track star <a href="Brian%20Whittle">Brian Whittle</a> he was a co-director at PB events.
